properties.description:
model info: pending

Sites: ABBY, BARR, BART, BLAN, BONA, CLBJ, CPER, DCFS, DEJU, DELA, DSNY, GRSM, GUAN, HARV, HEAL, JERC, JORN, KONA, KONZ, LAJA, LENO, MLBS, MOAB, NIWO, NOGP, OAES, ONAQ, ORNL, OSBS, PUUM, RMNP, SCBI, SERC, SJER, SOAP, SRER, STEI, STER, TALL, TEAK, TOOL, TREE, UKFS, UNDE, WOOD, WREF, YELL

Variables: abundance, richness

table:columns.name: reference_datetime
table:columns.description: ISO 8601(ISO 2019) datetime the forecast starts from (a.k.a. issue time); Only needed if more than one reference_datetime is stored in a single file. Forecast lead time is thus datetime-reference_datetime. In a hindcast the reference_date time will be earlier than the time the hindcast was actually produced (see pubDate in Section 3). Datetimes are allowed to be earlier than the reference_datetime if analysis/reforecast is run before the start of the forecast period. This variable was called start_time before v0.5 of the EFI standard.

table:columns.name: site_id
table:columns.description: For forecasts that are not on a spatial grid, use of a site dimension that maps to a more detailed geometry (points, polygons, etc.) is allowable. In general this would be documented in the external metadata (e.g., alook-up table that provides lon and lat); however in netCDF this could be handled by the CF Discrete Sampling Geometry data model.

table:columns.name: datetime
table:columns.description: ISO 8601(ISO 2019) datetime the forecast starts from (a.k.a. issue time); Only needed if more than one reference_datetime is stored in a single file. Forecast lead time is thus datetime-reference_datetime. In a hindcast the reference_date time will be earlier than the time the hindcast was actually produced (see pubDate in Section 3). Datetimes are allowed to be earlier than the reference_datetime if analysis/reforecast is run before the start of the forecast period. This variable was called start_time before v0.5 of the EFI standard.

table:columns.name: family
table:columns.description: For ensembles: “ensemble.” Default value if unspecified For probability distributions: Name of the statistical distribution associated with the reported statistics. The “sample” distribution is synonymous with “ensemble.” For summary statistics: “summary.”If this dimension does not vary, it is permissible to specify family as a variable attribute if the file format being used supports this (e.g.,netCDF).

table:columns.name: pubDate
table:columns.description: ISO 8601 (ISO 2019) datetime being predicted; follows CF convention http://cfconventions.org/cf-conventions/cf-conventions.html#time-coordinate. This variable was called time before v0.5of the EFI convention.For time-integrated variables (e.g., cumulative net primary productivity), one should specify the start_datetime and end_datetime as two variables, instead of the single datetime. If this is not provided the datetime is assumed to be the MIDPOINT of the integration period.

table:columns.name: mean
table:columns.description: mean forecast prediction for all ensemble members

table:columns.name: median
table:columns.description: median forecast prediction for all ensemble members

table:columns.name: sd
table:columns.description: standard deviation of all enemble member forecasts

table:columns.name: quantile97.5
table:columns.description: upper 97.5 percentile value of ensemble member forecasts

table:columns.name: quantile02.5
table:columns.description: upper 2.5 percentile value of ensemble member forecasts

table:columns.name: quantile90
table:columns.description: upper 90 percentile value of ensemble member forecasts

table:columns.name: quantile10
table:columns.description: upper 10 percentile value of ensemble member forecasts

1.title: Database Access
1.description:
Use `arrow` for remote access to the database. This R code will return results for this model within the NEON Ecological Forecasting Aquatics theme.

### R

```{r}
# Use code below

all_results <- arrow::open_dataset(s3://anonymous@bio230014-bucket01/neon4cast-scores/parquet/beetles/model_id=EFI_avg_null?endpoint_override=sdsc.osn.xsede.org)
df <- all_results |> dplyr::collect()

```
       

You can use dplyr operations before calling `dplyr::collect()` to `summarise`, `select` columns, and/or `filter` rows prior to pulling the data into a local `data.frame`. Reducing the data that is pulled locally will speed up the data download speed and reduce your memory usage.
